samples.question: Okay, if you are ready, could you begin speaking about it?

And for sure, it is one of the largest companies in the world. So everyone knows about it. And what I found it successful about Samsung, and I actually started about it when I was young, it was one of my teachers when I was in high school. And it was very fascinating to get to know how and how he got successful because if I am not wrong, the CEO in the beginning was selling rice cakes and he got so, you know, he was very, determined to succeed. So, I always find it very, very fascinating. And, however, when it comes to the working environment, I have a lot of friends that work for Samsung and it is very competitive. And, I mean, this is probably my personal opinion, but I, I do think it is, it is not one of the best working environment. it is very hard. it is, it is tough. You have to work for a lot of Howard and even just to get in. I know that the selection, they have like four interviewers. So I do not know if I would work there, but for sure it is a very successful company. And, what I would say is like different from any other company when it comes to Samsung is that they sell everything. Like you can go to a Samsung store and just to buy a TV or, of course a phone and you can also buy a fridge or I do not know, like an air conditioner. So it is something that I always find so, unique and something that is very different from most of other competitors when it comes to, companies and organizations. Thank you for answering all those questions.

samples.question: Is there a good way to give constructive feedback to someone about something?
samples.transcript: Yes, I definitely think there is and this is something that I have learned about in one of the courses I am studying at uni too, which was about sports coaching. So how we can give constructive feedback and help our students to learn to learn from their mistakes. And I think it is really important when giving constructive feedback to say something positive first, to make sure you are not too negative and that you do not have a negative tone to your voice, that you are happy. and that you are just generally trying to help them. You want to give off the vibe that you are just trying to help them and not that you are trying to put them down. I think it is one of the worst things when someone's telling you something and you know they are just trying to let you down and trying to make you feel bad about yourself. So I always try and start with something positive and then say, how about we try this or how about next time you do this? I think always phrasing it as a question is also a more sensitive way to approach the topic. In pronunciation there is a feature of, of language which is called the weak form. The weak form is when we do not put the stress on the, the word. And if you go back and listen to Romy, she very often uses the weak form of the sound to, to see, to do. We do not say to see or to do, we say to see, to do. And she uses this weak form with this sound called the schwa, the a sound, the t-t-t, to see, to do, to watch, to sing. And you will notice that she uses the weak form really well.

samples.question: Is there a good way to give constructive feedback to someone about something?

You want to give off the vibe that you are just trying to help them and not that you are trying to put them down. Now in her answer she said I wear sandals because you do not need socks for sandals and that is a compound sentence but she is explaining the reason why, Which is wonderful. I really like that. And then she starts, these little errors start slipping through. She said, and it is easy, easier to wear and it is comfortable. And the problem here is that she is referring to the wrong type of noun. She is referring to a singular noun. And actually she is talking about sandals. And the correct form, the correct pronoun there should be they are easier to wear and they are, they are more comfortable. And so she is mixing up the singulars and plurals there. But then she redeemed herself and she says, because I do a lot of sport. Notice there how she is changed the because to because. Because I do a lot of sport and lots of people think that the IELTS speaking test is a formal test and that you cannot contract words, you cannot shorten words. Well that is actually a myth and the word cause is absolutely appropriate and acceptable in the test. So I encourage you, if you can use it naturally, then definitely think about that. Then she is used words like sneakers. I, I also, she said also I wear sneakers as well. She is actually repeating two cohesive devices there. She is using also and as well together. Probably one of them would be redundant and she said like fencing and badminton. Good start. I am just a little bit concerned about these little grammar slips that are coming through.

samples.question: Calm down, ask the examiner, can you repeat the question or what does that mean?
samples.transcript: Or just take a few seconds to think about it and then calmly answer the question. You are extremely fluent, but you could do with slowing down a little bit. Fluency is not about speed, really. It is about can you speak without unnatural pauses and hesitations and things like that. You do not have a lot of, I do not know. you are not doing a lot of that. you are just speaking normally. you are speaking very quickly. Listen to the speed that I am speaking at. Like do not have to match me or anything like that. But I do not speak like this when I am speaking to my friends or my family. I would be speaking very quick, quickly compared to this. But because I am speaking to you and I want you to understand what I am saying, I am slowing things down. So fluency is a strength. but answering the question and a little bit of a weakness. vocabulary, you have a very wide ranging vocabulary. you are able to use very topic specific words, and deal with most topics very, very well. so I think vocabulary is probably your biggest strength. Grammar, you do have some little systematic errors like this. If I have enough saving, I would try to be a freelancer for one or two year. it is kind of not that hygiene enough. At least I know three language. it is totally different. But I think many of your grammar errors unusually could be related to pronunciation, which I think is your biggest weakness. Not criticizing you or anything like that. We all have strengths and weaknesses. it is fine. it is interesting you are from Myanmar. because you have, I do not deal with many Burmese students. I have been there and I have, I have taught there, but I, I, there is not a huge number, but it is interesting that you have a weakness that many Vietnamese students have, which is called final sounds. So the final sounds of a word, Vietnamese students, and you do this as well, they will often cut off the last sound. So for example, time becomes Thai. Think. Think. So you would not say think you would think, or thin, or thin, or thin. you are not saying the final sound often. Or sometimes you would miss S's off the ends of words. So that is important sometimes because tenses can often be indicated with the final sound. Like I start or I started. Like the final sign makes the difference in the tense or plural endings can change the grammar. So it is kind of relaxations, you know, so there is sometimes you are mixing those things up as well. So the final signs do affect your grammar score as well, but there are a lot of systematic errors, which means the same error is coming up again and again. So those would be the two areas that I would work on the most focusing on saying every, every syllable, especially the last syllable. Sound could solve a lot of problems because we are solving the pronunciation issue. we are solving the speaking too quickly issue and we are solving a lot of the grammar issues as well because often you are missing the last sign which affects grammar sometimes.

samples.question: How have you studied English and what tips or advice would you give to other students studying English and preparing for IELTS?
samples.transcript: Well, you know, here in the Philippines, as I said before, English is part of our curriculum. And we study from kindergarten until primary school, high school. So we really need to study English. But the thing is, we just do not have the environment to talk to someone in English. we have been hearing a lot of English advertisements like on TV, but the thing is we just do not have the environment or atmosphere to speak English. samples.question: Describe a creative solution you found to a problem.
samples.transcript: Working as a hotel manager, I face problems every single day. I had this experience where a VIP guest just checked in. We thought everything was smooth, everything was okay. But then in a couple of minutes, I saw one bad feedback in Google reviews saying like, the staff was not that much helpful. The staff was not smiling. And so one bad comment would definitely affect the image of the property. Me being the hotel manager, I always go to an easy solution, which is being more personalized and reaching myself to the guest. What I did was to give the guest a call in the room, check if the family was checked in well, if there is anything that she need, and point out about the review that she just posted in our property, about our property. And then ask her what made her feel that way What made her post that comment or that review in our website And I will always try to put myself in the shoe of the guest to understand more where they coming from and for me to be able to give a proper solution to her problem And I think the most creative solution in hospitality industry in dealing with complaints is being more personalized and just be yourself and have that connection with your guests. Like treat them as family. Because with that, I think it is easier to solve the issue. So we have been talking about creativity and solving problems in a creative way and we are going to continue to talk about that.

samples.question: And then you, why do people think that I am making mistakes or why am I getting a lower score?
samples.transcript: Because to you, it sounds totally fine because you have been speaking, let us call it Filipino English for many, many years. And no one has ever said that is an error. But when you do the IELTS test, again, you are moving to an English speaking country. They will pick up on those errors that you are completely unaware of. So for example, staff was not that much helpful. It should have been the staff were not very helpful. Or every household in Philippines, there is really gardens. Instead of in every household in the Philippines, there are gardens. I know exactly what you are saying. Yeah. there is no problem with meaning, but there are a lot of those little, for example, subject verb agreement issues, article issues. there is some tense inconsistencies. So the way that the IELTS examiner will think about your grammar score is number of sentences with or without errors. So for example, let us say just using round numbers, let us say you spoke 100 sentences. If more than 50 of those sentences had grammatical errors in them, more than half, you would get about six for grammar. If more than 50 of those sentences had zero errors, those would be known as error-free sentences, you would get at least a band seven. In my opinion, there were more small, just small little errors in most sentences, so you would get a band six for grammar. This is extremely common for Filipino students, and this is one of the main reasons why they get 6.5. So their fluency is great. They answer the questions. Their vocabulary is quite good. Their pronunciation is excellent. But this grammar issue brings them down. That should be your main area of focus. So overall, you would be in and around 6.5 or 7 overall. Now for most people, 7 is, is, great for, from whatever they need to do. but 6.5 is often not good. depends on what you want to do. My, advice would be to really focus on grammar and that can be quite difficult because as I said before, a lot of these issues are ingrained because you have been making those errors for years and you, you do not know you have, you are even making them. It does not affect communication. So it is not a huge issue. It just depends on what score you are hoping to get.

Instead of in every household in the Philippines, there are gardens. I know exactly what you're saying. Yeah. There's no problem with meaning, but there are a lot of those little, for example, subject verb agreement issues, article issues. There's some tense inconsistencies. So the way that the IELTS examiner will think about your grammar score is number of sentences with or without errors. So for example, let's say just using round numbers, let's say you spoke 100 sentences. If more than 50 of those sentences had grammatical errors in them, more than half, you would get about six for grammar. If more than 50 of those sentences had zero errors, those would be known as error-free sentences, you would get at least a band seven. In my opinion, there were more small, just small little errors in most sentences, so you would get a band six for grammar. This is extremely common for Filipino students, and this is one of the main reasons why they get 6.5. So their fluency is great. They answer the questions. Their vocabulary is quite good. Their pronunciation is excellent. But this grammar issue brings them down. That should be your main area of focus. So overall, um, you would be in and around 6.5 or 7 overall. Now for most people, 7 is, is, um, great for, from whatever they need to do. Um, but 6.5 is often not good. Um, depends on what you want to do. My, uh, advice would be to really focus on grammar and that can be quite difficult because as I said before, a lot of these issues are ingrained because you've been making those errors for years and you, you don't know you've, you're even making them. It doesn't affect communication. So it's not a huge issue. It just depends on what score you're hoping to get.

samples.question: When the examiner asks Anthony, when is the last time you went shopping there?
samples.transcript: Anthony has difficulty explaining that he went shopping there about a week ago. This sentence is way too simple for band five or higher. He should have immediately connected with an explanation because my family was running low on food and we needed to restock the fridge so we could cook at home and save money that way. This kind of compound complex sentence would be the way to earn those high scores. Giving a simple answer as Anthony did would be a band four. Poor grammar and unfinished sentences continue to degrade Anthony's overall score for the speaking section. In order to avoid this, a couple of tricks that you can follow are to reflect the grammar of the questions. When asked how have grocery stores changed in the past few decades, you should respond by using the question and using the grammar, stating they have changed a lot in the last 10 to 20 years. Nowadays, most grocery stores offer a wide range of foods from around the world. By using the question to start your response, you are able to build momentum and fluency. But of course, this takes practice. Pay attention to building your vocabulary using connective words as often as possible and paying attention to good strategy, answering, explaining, and giving examples. Follow these tips and you will for sure get into those band 7, 8, and even 9 levels on your next IELTS exam.

samples.question: Why do people want to learn a foreign language?
samples.transcript: I think that depends a bit on the person, but probably the most common motivation is to be able to talk to people from other countries who have a different cultural background, who speak a different language. Because I think that being able to speak a foreign language really opens doors to you. Because even if you go to a different country, if you do not speak the language, people are less willing to share information with you. And if you do approach the people in their own language, they are usually very glad to help you out and to explain more. So what is the best way to learn a foreign language Through reading through writing or through speaking Yeah For me personally it listening and speaking and just a bit of kind of trial and error but I do think that depends a lot on the person and their personality because I think an introvert person would probably rather study at home and read and write and study maybe the grammar rather than approach a different person directly And, practice their speaking skills.

Because even if you go to a different country, if you don't speak the language, people are less willing to share information with you. And if you do approach the people in their own language, they are usually very glad to help you out and to explain more. So what is the best way to learn a foreign language Through reading through writing or through speaking Yeah For me personally it listening and speaking and just a bit of kind of trial and error Um but I do think that depends a lot on um the person and their personality because I think an introvert person would probably rather study at home and read and write and study maybe the grammar rather than approach a different person directly And, um, practice their speaking skills.

samples.question: Are you ready?
samples.transcript: Let us jump straight into part one of the speaking test. In part one, the examiner will begin by introducing themselves, then asking you to state your name and show your identification. Then, they will ask you three sets of questions about familiar topics. The first set usually asks you general questions about yourself, such as your work or study, your home, or the place where you live. The second and third sets are personal questions about familiar topics like the food you like, your hobbies, people you spend time with, and so on. you will get up to 12 questions in this part, and it is important to know how to answer them well in the time given. But do not worry, today you will only get four part one questions. Here are my tips for part one. First, give extended answers. As a general rule, I would say try to talk for around 20 seconds for each answer. that is the equivalent of about two to three written sentences. Try to add more information to your response, such as giving an example or a reason to explain your answer. Also, make sure your answers have complete sentences. do not just give single word answers. Finally, there are no right or wrong answers to the questions, but what you say should answer the question. Now, it is time for you to try part one. I am going to ask you one set of questions, and you will have 20 seconds to answer each. And to get the most out of today's practice test, I recommend you record your answers so you can go back and check how you went.

samples.question: And why I enjoyed it?
samples.transcript: Well, I had not seen Alex in 3 years, so it was a chance to reconnect and reminisce. Notice I am noting some strong vocab here. And I also enjoyed it because it showed our friendship is still strong. And now I will give my full response. Listen for my use of vocabulary and grammar structures, how I develop the topic and link my ideas and my pronunciation. I am going to talk about a time when I really enjoyed sharing a meal with a friend. It happened about a year ago when I met up with my old friend, Alex. we would been close in university, but after graduating, life got busy and we lost touch. In fact, it had been almost 3 years since we would last seen each other. So, we decided to catch up over dinner. We chose a cozy Chinese restaurant in the city that specialized in hot pot. It was a great choice because hot pot is such a social meal. You sit around a steaming pot cooking your own food and it naturally creates conversation. The atmosphere in the restaurant was warm and lively with the sound of bubbling broth and people chatting all around us. We ordered a vegetarian hot pot which was perfect because Alex is vegetarian. There was a huge variety of fresh ingredients, mushrooms, tofu, leafy greens, and noodles. I remember the spicy broth being absolutely delicious, and we kept adding more ingredients as we talked. The whole experience felt interactive, which made the meal even more enjoyable.

samples.question: [Transcript chunk 1]
samples.transcript: Hi and welcome to a E helps IELTS test preparation videos in this video you will see a native Canadian English speaker who scores about an 8.5 for lots more help with the academic IELTS for different parts of the exam as well as the speaking section please visit us there and join the full course ok so just before we look at the speaking interview let us quickly discuss what you need to remember when you are thinking about your score for the speaking section of the IELTS so basically there will be 3 different factors that the markers of the IELTS will be looking at when they are judging your speaking interview the first point is natural speech so natural speech means how similar is your speaking to a native speakers so this includes pronunciation this includes your intonation so you are up and down in your sentences your enunciation so how well do you project your words of course your use of natural fillers like and use of slangs like want to Ghana use of idioms and of course self correction if you make a mistake do you stop and say oh sorry what I meant to say was or do you just simply correct yourself this is all part of natural speaking the second factor that they will be looking at very closely is coherence so this means do you answer the questions accurately do you stay on topic and do you give a complete and clear answer is it easy to understand what you are trying to save do not go off-topic do not just keep talking about anything and everything until the examiner stops you because you will lose scores when you have finished answering a question just thought the examiner will ask you the next one so it is important to be.

And that was like a big disappointment because I did not even get a seven like a C1. And then I took the exam twice at the age of 15 and got an overall of an eight and then I scored 8.5 at the age of 16.

samples.question: That grammar error becomes ingrained and then you go and do an IELTS test or you move to an English-speaking country and then you why do people think that I am making mistakes or why am I getting a lower score?
samples.transcript: Because to you it sounds totally fine because you have been speaking let us call it Filipino English for many many years and no one has ever said that is an error but when you do the IELTS test again you are moving to an English-speaking country they will pick up on those errors that you are completely unaware of so for example staff was not that much helpful it should have been the staff were not very helpful or every household in Philippines there is really gardens Instead of in every household in the Philippines, there are gardens. I know exactly what you are saying. >> there is no problem with meaning, but there are a lot of those little, for example, subjectverb agreement issues, article issues. there is some tense inconsistencies. So, the way that the IELTS examiner will think about your grammar score is number of sentences with or without errors. So for let us say just using round numbers, let us say you spoke 100 sentences. If more than 50 of those sentences had grammatical errors in them, more than half, you would get a band six for grammar. If more than 50 of those sentences had zero errors, those would be known as error-free sentences. You would get at least a band seven. In my opinion, there were more small just small little errors in most sentences. So you would get a band six for grammar. This is extremely common for Filipino students and this is one of the main reasons why they get 6.5. So their fluency is great. They answer the questions. Their vocabulary is quite good. Their pronunciation is excellent but this grammar issue brings them down. That should be your main area of focus. So overall you would be in and around 6.5 or seven overall. Now, for most people, seven is is great for from whatever they need to do. but 6.5 is often not good. depends on what you want to do. My advice would be to really focus on grammar and that can be quite difficult because as I said before a lot of these issues are ingrained because you have been making those errors for years and you you do not know you you are even making them. It does not affect communication so it is not a huge issue. It it just depends on what score you are hoping to get.

samples.question: Then you say " the first thing that comes to my mind." This is the first idea that popped into your head, right?
samples.transcript: The way you use words is very good, but not entirely accurate. The examiner will take note of this. You tried to use connecting words, but it needs to be more accurate. The correct way would be "the first thing that comes to mind is." Then you continue, and it will be more accurate. You also used "however," which is also good. Using "in my perspective" is not entirely correct. From my perspective, you used the phrase "to be honest," or when you answer "yes" to a yes/no question, instead of just saying "yes," you would say "yes definitely." that is also a very good way to answer. So that is an overview of fluency and grammar. Regarding my pronunciation, my intonation is very good. I use variations in pitch to express my emotions. However, after listening for a while, it still sounds a bit flat. So, I am trying to practice at home to slightly increase the pitch, making it higher and lower. For example, "Oh, I work in marketing and I need to research customer insights," it needs to go higher and lower. Currently, I do that, but the range is a bit low and short. If I increase the pitch, I will reduce it in the exam room. It will sound much better. Okay. And regarding pronunciation, I can clearly hear the words and use linking sounds – that is a plus. For example, I can say "someone who cares about cares about," or " gives me." I can pronounce the third-person singular form of the verb correctly – that is a plus. But I also make some mistakes with word formation. For example... Like " negotiate," I heard you pronounce it differently earlier, I do not remember exactly how, but it should be " negotiate." Then, you mispronounced "purchase" a few times, so it should be " purchase purchase." Okay, the second sound is "-," so the word "decide" should be pronounced "-," not " decided." Okay, pay attention.

samples.question: It should be "She always manages," right?
samples.transcript: The number "x" is correct, so you need to use the present simple tense. Then, when you say "when we," you might say " when we shopping," but it should be "when we shop" or "when we go shopping." Or "when we are shopping" would be more appropriate. Then you mentioned another point: "They are convenient to purchase." I forgot the context, but your point was that it is convenient for people to buy something. You need to use a dummy subject, "it is convenient for them to do something." Remember, "convenient for someone to do something" requires the "x" for correct grammar.
